												This is about as bare bones as you can get for a sports game,  Very limited options, no trades during the season, no free agency, no multiple seasons...  it's generally lacking in many areas which sports games have become known for in recent years.The good -  it has the official MLB license, which means real teams and players. The graphics are kind of meh, that normally doesn't matter in sports games but the player animations are rough, they glide rather than run.  Also it seems to have quite a few issues with fielding on line drives...Generally speaking, Super Mega Baseball is a far superior product, which is only held back by it's lack of a MLB license.  I'd only recommend this game if you're a massive hardcore fan of throwback games.  Even then it's a tough recommendation because the game just isn't very fun to play..

I used to play a game called Hardball! on my old Mac. And on my old Nintendo, Baseball Stars was the best. I was hoping RBI would be a throwback to those kinds of games, but not yet.Let's start with the cons:- Awful keyboard set up with no re-mapping. The controls are unintuitive and irritating to say the least. The right arrow key is assigned to "back" in the menu system. Really? And the mouse is unusable for the entire game, including navigating menus. But for some odd reason, the mouse arrow is still there anyway. Just allow me to map my own keys and use the mouse if I want. Trying to navigate through stats and other menus is really a pain in the @55. - Pitchers lose stamina very quickly. I'm lucky to get my starters to go 4 or 5 innings before they're tossing 60mph grapefruits (CPU, too). And I rarely use the "fast" or "slow" pitches or the left/right movement.- Pitchers don't seem to field groundballs. They will be available to catch the occasional pop-up, but a slow ground ball right to them? Nope. Through the legs and into center. EDIT FOR CLARIFICATION: the pitcher does get activated for some ground balls, such as a swinging bunt or weak grounder near him. But it's the grounders that are hit right at the pitcher where no attempt is made to field it, even though it looks like he's in fielding position and should be able to make a play on it.- Something is off with the overall "timing" of fielders, throwing, and baserunning. What I mean is, if I hit a gapper that rolls to the fence, I'll be lucky to get a double out of it, when it should be an easy stand-up double for even the slowest runner. I get thrown out fairly often trying to get to 2nd on what is typically a sure double. Want to tag up from third on a deep-ish fly ball? Good luck with that. It's nearly impossible. Want to score from 2nd with two outs on a single to the outfield? Good luck with that, too. I don't know if the runners are maybe just too slow or the fielders throw too fast. - Fielding glitches: I've had an outfielder catch a ball and then get stuck in the fence, unable to throw. Luckily, the computer runner didn't advance and eventually the play ended and went to the next at-bat. On one occasion the CPU had bases loaded with one out. It hit a routine grounder to my third baseman which should have been an easy 5-4-3 DP, but when I threw to 2nd, no one was there! The ball rolled all the way to the right field fence. When the CPU is fielding, it makes odd decisions. If I have runners on 1st and 2nd with less than 2 outs and I hit a grounder to an infielder, it tries to get the out at 3rd rather than go for the traditional DP. Even if I hit it to the second or first baseman! Also, with CPU runners on base, a routine grounder near 2nd base bag will not be picked up by the shortstop, even though he's running right over the ball! The second baseman is activated to field the ball, but he's no where near it. Similar scenarios happen between 1st and 2nd with pitcher, second baseman, and first baseman.- Baserunning glitch: Sometimes, when I have runners on base and I hit a fly ball, the CPU outfielder will catch it for the out, but not throw it in. It's just frozen there. The game will not continue unless I let one of my runners get out. Frustrating.- Quick-pitching by the CPU. Especially to start the game. If I'm visitor and have first at-bat, as soon as the pitching screen comes on, the first pitch is already on the way! It would be nice if there was a pause before the CPU starts pitching. Even for the later innings, although it's not as quick. But a slight pause would still be nice to get my batter set up or see who's pitching, etc. - Manual fielding (outfield) is kinda tough! Just when I think I figured out the fly ball indicator and sound, another ball goes way over my outfielder resulting in an extrabase-hit for the CPU. Is that just me? I'm reluctant to turn on the fielding assist because I want to do 100% of my fielding, but sometimes I wonder if the indicator is outta whack or I am. - Non-responsive throwing direction. Sometimes my fielder will not throw to the base I'm indicating with the WASD keys. For example, I'm clearly pushing W so my outfielder will throw to second, but the throw goes all the way home or to first. Initially I thought I was doing something incorrect, but I've been experimenting with this and there is definitely something else that is wrong. The pros:- Fun gameplay when it works. There is a sense of satisfaction when you time the swing well and get a nice solid hit somewhere. Or turn a tough 6-4-3 double play.- No annoying replays or cut scenes. I like the minimalist production. Even the homerun scenes are quick and unobtrusive. Most shots of foul balls are cut off so you are right back at the at-bat (although some scenes still follow the foul ball all the way out of the stadium for some reason). - Can call "time" even when pitcher is starting to throw. This is great because the CPU quick-pitches already, so if he's quick-pitching me to start an inning and I want to pinch hit, I can still call "time" before the pitcher releases so I can put in a pinch hitter.Anyway, I apologize for the long review. But I feel that discerning consumers want a real, honest review, including details. I will keep playing RBI in the hopes that more updates will come along to address these issues. But I can't help but be disappointed that they released a game like this with all these bugs and issues. It's so obviously a half-@55ed port from console and they didn't even bother to test it thoroughly. They're using paying consumers as testers. Not cool, guys. Not cool.

												SUMMARY:Well RBI Baseball is a very bare bones game with little features and fast gameplay, everything from a new batter to pitching changes or a pinch hitter is instant.  This game reminds me of the snes era of baseball games with updated graphics, and even less features than those had.  The game could be decent if the only problem was lack of common features found in all modern baseball games today but unfortunately it isn't.  I really wanted to look past the shortcomings and give this a good review but I can't, too many problems I've never experienced in any baseball game ever.  I only continue to play this because it's the only MLB baseball game on steam, so I deal with.  I can only recommend this game to you if you're in the same position, it's still not a good game.  Just be warned too some people say they lose their season after the regular season ends and the playoff starts, so be warned.You get Exhibition, Season, World Series, no playoffs, home run derby, or all star game.  No create a player, you can pinch hit but can not pinch run or sub a fielder.BUGS:This game is riddled with bugs, some of them just plain break the rules of the game, some are as follows:I fly out to left field, think game is frozen so hit buttons and the runners on 1st and 2nd move towards 2nd and 3rd, this gets the left fielder to throw the ball to 3rd, does not tag the runner, then throws to first who doesn't tag a runner either and I'm called out for a double play.  I did tag up.Again flew out to left thought was frozen, send runner from 1st and 2nd to 2nd and 3rd, he throws to 3rd then 1st, 1st baseman catches ball while runner is between 1st and 2nd and I'm called out triple play.  I had tagged up.I didn't know the how to control runners properly and ended a play with two runners on second, he threw the ball to second and both were called safe and they stayed there for the inning.Some very obvious balls called strikes and vice versa.Shortstop managed to knock the ball down once and it was called an error, which never would have happened after a leaping jump managed to keep the batter from extra bases and keep the ball in the infield.Had a ball clearly go foul but the umpire never called it and it was somehow in play.DUMB AI:I'm not on the hardest difficulty but the AI is till pretty dumb, making mistakes little leaguers wouldn't even make such as:Not taking the ball to first with two outs.Holding onto the ball instead of throwing back to infield/cutoff.Throwing from outfield to wrong base.Once threw the ball from the wall all the way to home plate and I scored while it slowly rolled to the catcher.Steals after ball crosses plate.Doesn't just miss, but starts to swing after the ball crosses plate.Sometimes will just throw terrible pitches, ball after ball after ball.I wish there was more I could say that is good about the game.   The hitting system is cool, it relies more on timing and location of ball on the bat rather than choosing if you're hitting for contact or power or manually controlling if you're going to pull or go for opposite field.I don't have that many hours in this game but there isn't much else to say except new bugs I'd find by playing.Oh, and the worst part, there is no damn CITGO sign at Fenway.  If they can't get the rights for the CITGO every game always has the sign with some other fake logo on it.  It's symbolic, and a huge oversight.  I'm probably nitpicking at this point but it is the only game I've played that didn't have it :(

												This game is a little disapointing in that it lacks depth... I haven't seen any injuries and the season mode is simplistic... With that caveat I DO reccomend this game as a fun, arcade style baseball game on PC. It has a few flaws - no pitch selection (slider, curveball, etc) and the pitchers get very tired quickly (3 innings max).  Fielding is a pain as well...   Also, it helps to have a controller  - I have a 360 controller.    For awhile the game was opening in a tiny box that could not be adjusted, but I think I got that sorted out...  If you can overlook a few bugs this is a great budget baseball title for the PC.

												I'm very happy to see a baseball game on the PC (aside from management sims).RBI is, as the other comments make clear, a classic arcade-style game, not a sim like The Show.So it should be reviewed as an arcade game, not a sim.---Pros----Controller and keyboard support.-Decent graphics.-Very good difficulty levels (not too easy, not too hard).-Full, 25-man, rosters.-Baseball on PC!-Season mode (up to 162 games).-Postseason mode.-Stat tracking.-All-star game scheduled in season.-Real MLB 2015 schedule for 162 game season mode!-Roster updates.-Unique ballparks.-Simply fun game!---Cons----No trading.-Graphics are only decent (player models look nothing like them).-Controls take some getting used to.-No HR derby.-NO TRADING!!!-If you press the swing button (A on Xbox controller), and you are hit by that pitch, it will still count as a strike...-Controls are sometimes unresponsive.-No AAA.-NO TRADING!!!!!!!!!!-No injuries.-AI is usually good, but can be pretty stupid.-Can't sim games in season mode.-No way to change controls (beyond "Classic" and "Modern" options).-NO TRADING!!!!! THIS IS A BIG DEAL!!!---Verdict---Overall, RBI 2015 is a fun game to fill that baseball gap, but it is far from perfect.If the bugs are ironed-out over the next few weeks, then it would be a no brainer to buy it. However, the bugs make it very frustrating at times. I have lost games due to AI issues or controller bugs.Even with its issues, RBI Baseball 2015 is a good baseball game and you should pick it up if you're a fan of classic arcade sports or baseball in general.
